<p><strong>The coronavirus outbreak</strong> is first and foremost a humanitarian crisis. As the situation evolves, the number-one priority for all companies must be the health and safety of employees and customers. At the same time, consumer-packaged-goods (CPG) leaders are facing an increasingly unpredictable and dynamic economic future, which will require thoughtful action to guide their business through the crisis.</p>
<p>Broadly, companies are focusing on three phases of action. The first is to navigate the now by safeguarding and protecting their employees, their customers, and the viability of their business.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7991355a-8aff-402d-ab96-0e1a1805bb58"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7991355a-8aff-402d-ab96-0e1a1805bb58" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">See Raphael Buck, Tracy Francis, Eldon Little, Jessica Moulton, and Samantha Phillips, <a href="/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/how-consumer-goods-companies-can-prepare-for-the-next-normal">How Consumer Goods companies can prepare for the next normal</a>, April 17, 2020, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span> The second is to reorient the business so it can navigate the disruption and plan for the recovery. Finally, the most sophisticated companies are already positioning their business for the next normal after the crisis. <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/revenue-growth-management-the-next-horizon">Revenue growth management (RGM)</a>the discipline of driving sustainable, profitable growth through a range of strategies around assortment, promotions, trade management, and pricinghas an important role to play in phases two and three.</p>
<p>RGM strategies have traditionally allowed top performers to generate profits that they can reinvest in innovation and brand building. Sustaining this approach through the crisis will be a major challenge, as some categories have seen demand crater, and most consumers are bracing for a weak economic outlook. (Only 35 percent of US consumers were optimistic or very optimistic about economic conditions after COVID-19,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e33c018b-c279-424d-b699-b15d43171fae"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e33c018b-c279-424d-b699-b15d43171fae" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">See <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/survey-us-consumer-sentiment-during-the-coronavirus-crisis">Survey: US Consumer sentiment during the coronavirus crisis</a>, April 29, 2020, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span> and only 10 to 15 percent in Italy, France, Spain, and the UK.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="845e1ea1-de41-4c74-a4e2-e125c848a8bd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="845e1ea1-de41-4c74-a4e2-e125c848a8bd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey & Company COVID-19 Consumer Pulse surveys, conducted globally between April 2 and April 19, 2020. All data relating to surveys are based on the McKinsey Global Consumer Pulse surveys conducted weekly since March 26 and expected to continue for the remainder of the COVID-19 pandemic. The most recent surveys for each country, usually including a comparison with the two previous weeks, are accessible at <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/global-surveys-of-consumer-sentiment-during-the-coronavirus-crisis">Global surveys of consumer sentiment during the coronavirus crisis</a>, on McKinsey.com. Not all dated surveys cited in this article are still available online, since older data are removed as surveys are updated. We will continue to provide in footnotes the relevant dates for which the data in this article were compiled, even if they are no longer available online.</span></span></span></a></span>)</p>
<h2>Navigate the disruption</h2>
<p>The crisis has affected consumer-goods companies in very different ways through changes in consumer behavior across several dimensions: category consumption, channel selection, shopper trip frequency, brand preference, and media consumption. (For an overview of these changes and their implications for demand, see <em><a href="/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/rapidly-forecasting-demand-and-adapting-commercial-plans-in-a-pandemic">Rapidly forecasting demand and adapting commercial strategies in a pandemic</a></em>.)</p>
<p>These changes in consumer behavior require a new type of rapid planning, with a high level of uncertainty around the magnitude and duration of changes in consumer behavior. We recommend a SPRINT approach, which can be completed in four to six weeks (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/marketing%20and%20sales/our%20insights/revenue%20growth%20management%20in%20the%20covid%2019%20crisis/svg-rgm-covid-response-exhibit-1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Navigating the crisis calls for rapid and coordinated execution of a SPRINT-based plan." src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/marketing%20and%20sales/our%20insights/revenue%20growth%20management%20in%20the%20covid%2019%20crisis/svg-rgm-covid-response-exhibit-1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The essence of the SPRINT model is to develop a view of the expected revenue and margin evolution of the business based on each category-level demand archetype, and then to design appropriate actions across multiple commercial dimensions. The SPRINT model is comprehensively laid out in <em><em><a href="/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/rapidly-forecasting-demand-and-adapting-commercial-plans-in-a-pandemic">Rapidly forecasting demand and adapting commercial strategies in a pandemic</a></em></em>. We focus here on the RGM component in step 5 (N):</p>
<p><em>Navigate RGM adjustments with caution.</em> Coupled with supply realities, any demand spikes or dropoffs will create opportunities and challenges for CPGs. With respect to the four core aspects of RGM (pricing, promotions, assortment and portfolio, and trade), companies need to tread carefully. Any action on RGM should abide by the principle of building stronger relationships with customers and consumers (for example, by extending payment terms for more vulnerable customers or by delaying planned price increases on essentials). At the same time, there will be value-driving actions to take (Exhibit 2).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/marketing%20and%20sales/our%20insights/revenue%20growth%20management%20in%20the%20covid%2019%20crisis/svg-rgm-covid-response-exhibit-2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="RGM in a crisis requires strategic choices." src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/marketing%20and%20sales/our%20insights/revenue%20growth%20management%20in%20the%20covid%2019%20crisis/svg-rgm-covid-response-exhibit-2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/how-we-help-clients">Marketing & Sales Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/how-we-help-clients/customer-lifecycle-management" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Visit our Customer Lifecycle Management page</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<h2>Plan for the next normal</h2>
<p>Even as companies work nonstop to stabilize their business, we believe it is critical to allocate significant time to planning for the postcrisis phase. It can be as simple as executives spending a few hours every week thinking ahead, or as committed as assigning a specific team responsibility for creating RGM plans for 2021 and beyond. To succeed at RGM in the next normal, CPG companies need to focus on consumers, shoppers, and customers, and define scenarios for each.</p>
<h3>Consumers</h3>
<p><em>Product and brand preferencesleading to assortment and pricing changes</em></p>
<p>Stockpiling and product unavailability are disrupting consumers traditional preferences for specific brands or product attributes, especially in categories deemed essential. As a result, 30 to 40 percent of US consumers and 65 to 75 percent of those in India and Vietnam have already tried alternative brands or products during COVID-19.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c575410e-f01b-4821-93a3-3d313bc4d6c3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c575410e-f01b-4821-93a3-3d313bc4d6c3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Consumer Pulse surveys: US 3/1920, 2020; India 4/1013, 2020; Vietnam 4/1821, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> The expected postcrisis recession is likely to exacerbate this trend as consumers look for and switch to more affordable options.</p>
<p>To respond, CPGs will need to make assortment and pricing changes:</p>
<ul>
    <li>Re-evaluate portfolio positioning and pack-price architecture, and consider whether to change the pricing for certain SKUs or launch new packs that are more affordable or convenient. One coffee-subscription company saw growing consumer demand for its home-delivered coffee and made a five-pound pack, normally reserved for wholesale, available to end consumers online, which was an instant hit.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0c1a9fa1-36cd-4599-b2f8-83306345c294"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0c1a9fa1-36cd-4599-b2f8-83306345c294" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Meggen Taylor, Trade coffee launches a five-pound bag to satisfy consumer demand and to keep their roasting partners in business during the pandemic, <em>Forbes</em>, April 7, 2020, www.forbes.com.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li>Consider whether they need new sub-brands with a differentiated proposition, specifically as an affordability play or to fulfill needs that matter more to consumers post-COVID-19.</li>
    <li>Consider whether to invest in a specific growth category through innovation or M&A. As an example, many manufacturers of beauty and personal-care products have started to produce alcohol gels to support health workers and their communities. Now, with increased demand for hygiene products, should these become part of their standard offering?</li>
    <li>Address health concerns, in particular hygiene-conscious packaging. Examples are beverage companies adding aluminum-foil tops on cans or fresh-food producers packing products. Notably, these changes will also need to align with consumers rising standards on sustainability.</li>
</ul>
<p><em>Consumption occasionsleading to assortment and promotions changes</em></p>
<p>The shift to at-home consumption may become structural as consumer habits around working from home or spending social time outside change. Since the impact would vary by category, consumer-goods companies need to have a clear understanding of this evolution by holding new consumer-usage panels more frequently or using new household-penetration data in more detail.</p>
<p>Early evidence from China also suggests that some of the consumption occasions most impacted by COVID-19 are not likely to return quickly to precrisis levels, and recovery is not uniform across the country. In Tier-1 cities, sales in restaurants and food service in early March (with reopening rates above 90 percent) were still 40 percent lower than in December 2019.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0f386736-3ba1-4b2f-bcc9-17a88954776c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0f386736-3ba1-4b2f-bcc9-17a88954776c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">MIYA payment engine data. Tier-1 cities are Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>CPG companies will need to leverage these insights to develop new occasion-led assortment and promotion strategy changes. If occasion insights are not yet a significant input to activation and innovation strategy, now may be the time to bring them forward. This can lead to developing products better suited to new or more important occasions, reallocating communication investment toward them, and improving the activation of products to match the occasions. Several wine companies, for example, have started to offer virtual educational wine tastings, with complimentary at-home delivery.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about Periscope by McKinsey?</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/solutions/periscope/overview" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Visit our Solutions page to use advanced analytics solutions to drive revenue growth</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<h3>Shoppers</h3>
<p><em>Shopping occasions / missionsleading to promotions changes</em></p>
<p>Stock-up missions in grocery retail significantly increased during the initial crisis and may continue to be more functional, shorter, fewer in number, and higher in ticket value. In addition, the shopper may change: in China, male shoppers at brick-and-mortar stores increased more than 50 percent during the crisis.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e42fe259-5f84-4599-9fea-18d8381fb3a5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e42fe259-5f84-4599-9fea-18d8381fb3a5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Consumer Pulse surveys: China survey 3/2123, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>With consumers spending less time in stores, space for second placements is potentially restricted due to social distancing and a changing shopper profile. CPG companies need to redesign their promotional plans and reallocate budgets, including stimulating new-promotion volume uplifts, returns on investment, and reflecting changes in the assortment focus.</p>
<p><em>Channel and store preferencesleading to assortment and trade management changes</em></p>
<p>Shoppers are trying new ways of shopping and many may stick with them, leading to dramatic channel shifts:</p>
<ul>
    <li>E-commerce is growing, albeit at vastly different speeds in different places. US grocery e-commerce household penetration increased from 13 percent before the pandemic to more than 31 percent in late March.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fbf66757-103e-4a47-bdd1-e1fb809ed65d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fbf66757-103e-4a47-bdd1-e1fb809ed65d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Brick Meets Click and ShopperKit Online Shopping surveys: August 21-23, 2019, and March 23-25, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> This acceleration is likely to remain to some extent after lockdowns are over, with consumers in Asia expecting to shop online significantly more after the crisis than they did before: +15 percent in China, +16 percent in Indonesia, +38 percent in India, and +47 percent in Vietnam.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7381fdeb-6790-4757-99c6-e15992ba8c46"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7381fdeb-6790-4757-99c6-e15992ba8c46" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Consumer Pulse surveys: Vietnam 4/1821/2020; China 4/813, 2020; Indonesia 4/1012, 2020; India 4/1013, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li>Bricks-and-mortar retail is seeing a substantial change in store mix and shopper experience. For example, in Europe, 14 percent of shoppers switched to a discount store, and in the US, 17 percent of shoppers were already going to new stores during the COVID-19 situation. In China, 50 percent of shoppers who had changed stores reported they do not intend to shift back.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="97f6854c-7589-41cc-b942-868dfb05eacd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="97f6854c-7589-41cc-b942-868dfb05eacd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Consumer Pulse surveys: Europe (including Italy, France, Germany, Spain, UK, and Portugal) 4/1619, 2020; US 3/1922, 2020; China 3/21 23, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
</ul>
<p>Various data sources and analysis techniques can help CPGs monitor these shopping habits very closely. For example, shopper surveys and geospatial-location data can shed light on how shopping behaviors and missions are changingand given how fast the crisis is evolving, weekly or monthly updates are desirable.</p>
<p>Companies should start positioning themselves now to succeed by:</p>
<ul>
    <li>accelerating efforts to win in growing purchasing channels such as e-commerce and click & collect, including expanding e-category management capabilities and providing easy-to-handle, e-commerce-specific packaging. A consumer products brand, for example, refocused its promotional budget on its own website, offering over 50 percent discounts to match customers changes in channel focus.</li>
    <li>ensuring sufficient product availability and distribution of a must-have assortment across all store types. Companies could also consider having a presence in the discount channel, provided they carefully assess the tradeoffs of such a move.</li>
</ul>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Rapid Revenue Recovery A road map for post-COVID-19 growth" src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/marketing%20and%20sales/our%20insights/rapid%20revenue%20recovery%20a%20road%20map%20for%20post%20covid%2019%20growth/standard-rrr-862880916.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Rapid Revenue Recovery: A road map for post-COVID-19 growth</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/rapid-revenue-recovery-a-road-map-for-post-covid-19-growth" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the article</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><em>Customersleading to trade-management changes</em></p>
<p>In light of the changes to channel and store preferences described above, CPG companies will need to focus efforts with customers along four dimensions:</p>
<p><em>Strengthen operational relationships to ensure the basics are in place</em>for example, ensuring an effective supply chain to make sure there is always stock.</p>
<p><em>Support customers who may be under critical pressures</em>this can include extending payment terms or temporarily enabling consignment-based selling models. For example, an alcoholic-beverage company is encouraging outlet consumers to buy gift cards that can be redeemed later, helping to protect one of its core channels.</p>
<p><em>Reassess focus of investments across customers</em>, given likely changes in the channel landscape, and who are going to be the new winners. CPG companies will need to redefine their customer segmentation and purposefully tie investment amounts, components, and size to the new segmentation.</p>
<p><em>Redefine trade-terms agreements with retailers</em>, as they are being disrupted by changes in shopper habits and preferences. This will include changes to:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>promotion plans</em>as noted above, promotional uplifts and returns are likely to fundamentally change, and CPG companies will need to reset promotional plans agreed with retailers, redefining terms, in particular fixed-sum payments.</li>
    <li><em>growth bonus thresholds</em>as shoppers spend more on essentials and less on discretionary items, growth thresholds may be arbitrarily hit or become completely out of reach.</li>
    <li><em>timing of annual negotiations</em>negotiations between CPGs and retailers typically start gearing up at the end of Q3 and accelerate in Q4. However, in light of the crisis, CPGs may want to delay negotiations until they have more clarity on what the next normal looks like, negotiate different components at different times, or agree to more flexible terms. At all times, companies should avoid being locked into a contract that has not been adjusted for the new reality.</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p>There is no playbook for navigating a global pandemic, and there are shifts that will be hard to anticipate. But experience shows that companies that take a proactive approach, repositioning themselves to navigate the disruption and planning ahead for the post-crisis world as best they can, stand the best chance of not only surviving but coming out on the other side stronger. Companies that already have a dedicated RGM function should be putting that capability at the forefront of their effort. The actions they help direct should deliver for consumers and shoppers and strengthen relationships with key customers.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><a href="/our-people/simon-land"><strong>Simon Land</strong></a> is a partner in McKinseys Dsseldorf office; <a href="/our-people/sheldon-lyn"><strong>Sheldon Lyn</strong></a> a partner in the Southern California office; <a href="/our-people/ryan-murphy"><strong>Ryan Murphy</strong></a> is a partner in the Atlanta office; <strong>Pieter Reynders</strong> is an associate partner in the Brussels office; and <strong>Joel Saa-Seoane</strong> is an associate partner in the Washington DC office.</p>

<p>The authors wish to thank Kevin Bright, Gonzalo Buisel, Matthieu Francois, Aleksandra Nadezhdina, and Ren Schmutzler for their contributions to this article.</p></div></div></div></section><section management remain, but CPG companies will need to pivot fast to respond to the crisis and lay the groundwork for the next phase."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"CPG companies that proactively manage revenues and plan ahead for the new, post-COVID normal are best positioned to succeed."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2020-05-15T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe coronavirus outbreak\u003c/strong\u003e is first and foremost a humanitarian crisis. As the situation evolves, the number-one priority for all companies must be the health and safety of employees and customers. At the same time, consumer-packaged-goods (CPG) leaders are facing an increasingly unpredictable and dynamic economic future, which will require thoughtful action to guide their business through the crisis.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBroadly, companies are focusing on three phases of action. The first is to navigate the now by safeguarding and protecting their employees, their customers, and the viability of their business.[[footnote 1]] The second is to reorient the business so it can navigate the disruption and plan for the recovery. Finally, the most sophisticated companies are already positioning their business for the next normal after the crisis. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/revenue-growth-management-the-next-horizon\"\u003eRevenue growth management (RGM)\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;the discipline of driving sustainable, profitable growth through a range of strategies around assortment, promotions, trade management, and pricing\u0026mdash;has an important role to play in phases two and three.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRGM strategies have traditionally allowed top performers to generate profits that they can reinvest in innovation and brand building. Sustaining this approach through the crisis will be a major challenge, as some categories have seen demand crater, and most consumers are bracing for a weak economic outlook. (Only 35 percent of US consumers were optimistic or very optimistic about economic conditions after COVID-19,[[footnote 2]] and only 10 to 15 percent in Italy, France, Spain, and the UK.[[footnote 3]])\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eNavigate the disruption\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe crisis has affected consumer-goods companies in very different ways through changes in consumer behavior across several dimensions: category consumption, channel selection, shopper trip frequency, brand preference, and media consumption. (For an overview of these changes and their implications for demand, see \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/rapidly-forecasting-demand-and-adapting-commercial-plans-in-a-pandemic\"\u003eRapidly forecasting demand and adapting commercial strategies in a pandemic\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e.)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese changes in consumer behavior require a new type of rapid planning, with a high level of uncertainty around the magnitude and duration of changes in consumer behavior. We recommend a \u0026ldquo;SPRINT\u0026rdquo; approach, which can be completed in four to six weeks (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe essence of the SPRINT model is to develop a view of the expected revenue and margin evolution of the business based on each category-level demand archetype, and then to design appropriate actions across multiple commercial dimensions. The SPRINT model is comprehensively laid out in \u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/rapidly-forecasting-demand-and-adapting-commercial-plans-in-a-pandemic\"\u003eRapidly forecasting demand and adapting commercial strategies in a pandemic\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e. We focus here on the RGM component in step 5 (\u0026lsquo;N\u0026rsquo;):\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eNavigate RGM adjustments with caution.\u003c/em\u003e Coupled with supply realities, any demand spikes or dropoffs will create opportunities and challenges for CPGs. With respect to the four core aspects of RGM (pricing, promotions, assortment and portfolio, and trade), companies need to tread carefully. Any action on RGM should abide by the principle of building stronger relationships with customers and consumers (for example, by extending payment terms for more vulnerable customers or by delaying planned price increases on essentials). At the same time, there will be value-driving actions to take (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 2]]\n[[disruptor1up learnmore]]\n\u003ch2\u003ePlan for the next normal\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEven as companies work nonstop to stabilize their business, we believe it is critical to allocate significant time to planning for the postcrisis phase. It can be as simple as executives spending a few hours every week thinking ahead, or as committed as assigning a specific team responsibility for creating RGM plans for 2021 and beyond. To succeed at RGM in the next normal, CPG companies need to focus on consumers, shoppers, and customers, and define scenarios for each.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eConsumers\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eProduct and brand preferences\u0026mdash;leading to assortment and pricing changes\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStockpiling and product unavailability are disrupting consumers\u0026rsquo; traditional preferences for specific brands or product attributes, especially in categories deemed essential. As a result, 30 to 40 percent of US consumers and 65 to 75 percent of those in India and Vietnam have already tried alternative brands or products during COVID-19.[[footnote 4]] The expected postcrisis recession is likely to exacerbate this trend as consumers look for and switch to more affordable options.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo respond, CPGs will need to make assortment and pricing changes:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eRe-evaluate portfolio positioning and pack-price architecture, and consider whether to change the pricing for certain SKUs or launch new packs that are more affordable or convenient. One coffee-subscription company saw growing consumer demand for its home-delivered coffee and made a five-pound pack, normally reserved for wholesale, available to end consumers online, which was an instant hit.[[footnote 5]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eConsider whether they need new sub-brands with a differentiated proposition, specifically as an affordability play or to fulfill needs that matter more to consumers post-COVID-19.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eConsider whether to invest in a specific growth category through innovation or M\u0026amp;A. As an example, many manufacturers of beauty and personal-care products have started to produce alcohol gels to support health workers and their communities. Now, with increased demand for hygiene products, should these become part of their standard offering?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAddress health concerns, in particular hygiene-conscious packaging. Examples are beverage companies adding aluminum-foil tops on cans or fresh-food producers packing products. Notably, these changes will also need to align with consumers\u0026rsquo; rising standards on sustainability.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eConsumption occasions\u0026mdash;leading to assortment and promotions changes\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe shift to at-home consumption may become structural as consumer habits around working from home or spending social time outside change. Since the impact would vary by category, consumer-goods companies need to have a clear understanding of this evolution by holding new consumer-usage panels more frequently or using new household-penetration data in more detail.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEarly evidence from China also suggests that some of the consumption occasions most impacted by COVID-19 are not likely to return quickly to precrisis levels, and recovery is not uniform across the country. In Tier-1 cities, sales in restaurants and food service in early March (with reopening rates above 90 percent) were still 40 percent lower than in December 2019.[[footnote 6]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCPG companies will need to leverage these insights to develop new occasion-led assortment and promotion strategy changes. If occasion insights are not yet a significant input to activation and innovation strategy, now may be the time to bring them forward. This can lead to developing products better suited to new or more important occasions, reallocating communication investment toward them, and improving the activation of products to match the occasions. Several wine companies, for example, have started to offer virtual educational wine tastings, with complimentary at-home delivery.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1up periscope]]\n\u003ch3\u003eShoppers\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eShopping occasions / missions\u0026mdash;leading to promotions changes\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStock-up missions in grocery retail significantly increased during the initial crisis and may continue to be more functional, shorter, fewer in number, and higher in ticket value. In addition, the shopper may change: in China, male shoppers at brick-and-mortar stores increased more than 50 percent during the crisis.[[footnote 7]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith consumers spending less time in stores, space for second placements is potentially restricted due to social distancing and a changing shopper profile. CPG companies need to redesign their promotional plans and reallocate budgets, including stimulating new-promotion volume uplifts, returns on investment, and reflecting changes in the assortment focus.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eChannel and store preferences\u0026mdash;leading to assortment and trade management changes\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eShoppers are trying new ways of shopping and many may stick with them, leading to dramatic channel shifts:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eE-commerce is growing, albeit at vastly different speeds in different places. US grocery e-commerce household penetration increased from 13 percent before the pandemic to more than 31 percent in late March.[[footnote 8]] This acceleration is likely to remain to some extent after lockdowns are over, with consumers in Asia expecting to shop online significantly more after the crisis than they did before: +15 percent in China, +16 percent in Indonesia, +38 percent in India, and +47 percent in Vietnam.[[footnote 9]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eBricks-and-mortar retail is seeing a substantial change in store mix and shopper experience. For example, in Europe, 14 percent of shoppers switched to a discount store, and in the US, 17 percent of shoppers were already going to new stores during the COVID-19 situation. In China, 50 percent of shoppers who had changed stores reported they do not intend to shift back.[[footnote 10]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eVarious data sources and analysis techniques can help CPGs monitor these shopping habits very closely. For example, shopper surveys and geospatial-location data can shed light on how shopping behaviors and missions are changing\u0026mdash;and given how fast the crisis is evolving, weekly or monthly updates are desirable.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompanies should start positioning themselves now to succeed by:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eaccelerating efforts to win in growing purchasing channels such as e-commerce and click \u0026amp; collect, including expanding e-category management capabilities and providing easy-to-handle, e-commerce-specific packaging. A consumer products brand, for example, refocused its promotional budget on its own website, offering over 50 percent discounts to match customers\u0026rsquo; changes in channel focus.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eensuring sufficient product availability and distribution of a \u0026ldquo;must-have assortment\u0026rdquo; across all store types. Companies could also consider having a presence in the discount channel, provided they carefully assess the tradeoffs of such a move.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[disruptor1up readnext]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eCustomers\u0026mdash;leading to trade-management changes\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn light of the changes to channel and store preferences described above, CPG companies will need to focus efforts with customers along four dimensions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eStrengthen operational relationships to ensure the basics are in place\u003c/em\u003e\u0026mdash;for example, ensuring an effective supply chain to make sure there is always stock.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eSupport customers who may be under critical pressures\u003c/em\u003e\u0026mdash;this can include extending payment terms or temporarily enabling consignment-based selling models. For example, an alcoholic-beverage company is encouraging outlet consumers to buy gift cards that can be redeemed later, helping to protect one of its core channels.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eReassess focus of investments across customers\u003c/em\u003e, given likely changes in the channel landscape, and who are going to be the \u0026ldquo;new winners.\u0026rdquo; CPG companies will need to redefine their customer segmentation and purposefully tie investment amounts, components, and size to the new segmentation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eRedefine trade-terms agreements with retailers\u003c/em\u003e, as they are being disrupted by changes in shopper habits and preferences. This will include changes to:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003epromotion plans\u003c/em\u003e\u0026mdash;as noted above, promotional uplifts and returns are likely to fundamentally change, and CPG companies will need to reset promotional plans agreed with retailers, redefining terms, in particular fixed-sum payments.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003egrowth bonus thresholds\u003c/em\u003e\u0026mdash;as shoppers spend more on essentials and less on discretionary items, growth thresholds may be arbitrarily hit or become completely out of reach.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003etiming of annual negotiations\u003c/em\u003e\u0026mdash;negotiations between CPGs and retailers typically start gearing up at the end of Q3 and accelerate in Q4. However, in light of the crisis, CPGs may want to delay negotiations until they have more clarity on what the next normal looks like, negotiate different components at different times, or agree to more flexible terms. At all times, companies should avoid being locked into a contract that has not been adjusted for the new reality.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere is no playbook for navigating a global pandemic, and there are shifts that will be hard to anticipate. But experience shows that companies that take a proactive approach, repositioning themselves to navigate the disruption and planning ahead for the post-crisis world as best they can, stand the best chance of not only surviving but coming out on the other side stronger. Companies that already have a dedicated RGM function should be putting that capability at the forefront of their effort. The actions they help direct should deliver for consumers and shoppers and strengthen relationships with key customers.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2020-05-14T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSee Raphael Buck, Tracy Francis, Eldon Little, Jessica Moulton, and Samantha Phillips, \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/how-consumer-goods-companies-can-prepare-for-the-next-normal\"\u003eHow Consumer Goods companies can prepare for the next normal\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo;
